speaker: Speaker 2
text: Hello.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: I'm Jack.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Hello. My name is Anne. Nice to meet you.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It's a pleasure. So, this is the house.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Hmm.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It's really beautiful.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, yes, it is. But but it's very difficult to keep clean.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Sorry. Not a good start.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Don't worry.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Your accent is very clear. Where are you from?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'm from Oxford.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Wow, Oxford. 100% English.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes. And you are American. Is that right?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Yes. But my family is from Italy, Bologna.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, Italy is wonderful. My sister is in Italy at the moment.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Where?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: She's in Rome, studying Italian painters. She's really happy. Italians are so friendly. Oh, that's Alice.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Hi.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: She's also part of the family.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It's nice to meet you, Alice.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: So this is Jack, the new flatmate.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Yes. And he is from

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Nice to meet you, Jack.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: I'm from Sydney, in Australia. And you are a Capricorn.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Yes! Amazing! I come from America. I'm from New York.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Wow, the big Apple.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Yes. Okay. Um, can I put my things in the bedroom?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Let me help you.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Hey, this is nice.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: I'm glad you like it. It's a Mexican hat.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: You look great.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: And what is this?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It's an African mask.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Is it magic?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Of course. But look at this.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: A bottle of Italian wine. Do you like wine?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Cheers.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Cheers.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Mm.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Mm, this wine is very good.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Mm, yes, it's really good.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Mm.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: By the way, you're very lucky. Look, it's raining now.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Yes, I am lucky.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, that's my photo album there. The pictures of all my friends are in here.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, that's interesting, show me.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: So, this is Mary. She's from Ireland. Her mother and father are Greek.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Her parents are from Greece?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes, they're Greek.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Huh.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: They're from Athens.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, and who's that?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Uh, that's Alice.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: No, that's not Alice.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, yes it is after a party. A Halloween party.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, that's funny. And, oh, and who are they?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Well, uh, that's Sharon and Peter. They live in the flat near here. They're good friends.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: She's very pretty.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Mm.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Hello. My name is Jack. I'm the new flatmate. It's nice to meet you.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Hello Jack, I'm Peter Nash.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And Sharon?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, and this is Sharon.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: It's a pleasure.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: How are you, Sharon?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Fine, thanks.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, good, you're friends. But so guys, there's work in the kitchen for everyone.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: And you are a great cook.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Thank you, Jack.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Big announcement. Finally, I have all the points, and I can get that marvelous set of Chinese plates.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: What?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes, with the cookies. Help me fill in the form, Jack, please.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: All right. Let me see the questions. What's your name?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Are you joking?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, okay. A N N E. And what's your family name?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Um, my surname?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Yes.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Right. Uh, Baxter.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: B A X T E R. And what's your phone number?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Uh-huh.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Right.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: You have to remember, this is your telephone number, too.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: You're right.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Are you married?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: No, I'm single.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: A pretty girl like you is still single?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Stop it, Jack, please.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: For the moment, I'm single.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Next question, please. Where are you from?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Um, there are a lot of questions.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It's for your Chinese plates.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Okay, for the last time, I'm from England. From Oxford.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: A X F O R D.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: No.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: O X F O R D.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Just joking.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: It's okay.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: What's next?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Just two more questions. The address is?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: 45 Trinity Lane, Flat C.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: What's the postcode?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: EC1 4RN.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: E C 1 4 R N. And what's your job?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'm an employee in a publishing company.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, you're just the right person for me. I have a great love story to write.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Good morning, Alice. How are you?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Hi, Anne. Good morning.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: I'm fine, and you?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Fine, thanks.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Excuse me, where's my watch?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: I don't know. Isn't it under the magazines?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: No, it isn't. Are you sure?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Yes, I'm sure. It's not under the magazines, and and I'm late. I have an appointment at 8 o'clock.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Maybe it's here on the table.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: No, the watch isn't here.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Behind the apples, next to the pasta.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh! There it is! Thanks Alice.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: You're welcome, Anne. Bye.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, no. It's late.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Alice, what time is it?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Just a moment.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: It's half past 7.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Half past 7. My train is at 8 o'clock.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Hurry up, Jack, you're late.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, okay, where are my keys?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: They're here on the table.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, thanks, Alice. Now, another problem. Where is my sweater?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Maybe it's on the chair.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: No, it isn't. Where is it?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Calm down, Jack. You're wearing it.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh. Thanks, Alice.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: You're a lifesaver.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Hurry up. Go, go, go.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Too much stress. I must go back to bed again.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, okay, girls, what time is the dinner tonight at the restaurant?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Uh, it's at half past eight.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Are you sure? I think it's at half past nine.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, guys, when is it?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'm certain it's at 8:30. Sorry, it's at 9:30.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, okay, it's tonight, right?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Yes, it's tonight. But what time is it, by the way?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The clock over there, it's at a quarter to 7.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: So if it's after 6, Sharon's at home.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: No, she isn't. She's at work.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: No, usually she comes back home after 6.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Hi Sharon. Good evening.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Hi guys.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Sharon, please help us. What time is the dinner tonight?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: It's quite late, it's at half past ten.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: See, Jack, half past ten.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, you're right, I'm wrong.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Women.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Hello, Anne.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, it's you, Peter. Look. This is it!

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Look at what?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: My office. Here, near my bed.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Oh, I see.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: By the way, where are the office supplies?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: The computer supplies are in that cupboard over there. The folders, pencils, pens, etc. are here in this cupboard. And I also have two chairs.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Oh, good, at least for everyone.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: No, they are not. Don't touch anything, please.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Okay, so you say you have all of the office supplies?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: No, not really. Um, there isn't a fax machine.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: There aren't all the programs I need on my computer.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And I guess you have an answering machine. Is it useful?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I don't need an answering machine. I answer the telephone myself.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Okay, you're right. This office is nice.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And if you need a fax machine, I have one in my apartment.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Wait a minute. Something is missing. Where's the coffee machine? All offices have a coffee machine.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'm afraid there isn't one here. There's a staff kitchen on the other side of the house. In the kitchen.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: We can have some coffee there.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Good idea.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Do you want milk with your coffee? There's a bottle in the back of the fridge.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: I prefer it without milk, but with some sugar.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, I'm afraid there isn't any sugar.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Well, that's okay. Black coffee is good too.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Do you have any of those great cookies?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Oh, yes.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: There are some cookies over here.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Peter speaking.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: What?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: An audition.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: No, not at all.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: I'm free. Great.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Bye.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Well, finally, an audition.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Wonderful! When?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Next Monday, at the Opera Theater. These cookies are fantastic. Are there any more?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: There are some more in the box.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Thank you. Bye, Ann. Time for music.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Hey! Take your dirty napkin away from my kitchen!

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Mmm!

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Oh.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes. I always go shopping on Saturdays. The first thing I do on Saturday is drive to the supermarket.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: I sometimes go shopping on Saturdays, but usually I sleep late. I'm always so tired on Saturdays.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'm never tired on the weekend. The weekend is a time for fun. I paint, go jogging, go out with some friends.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Unfortunately, I sometimes have to study.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Oh, I sometimes do a little work at the weekend.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: When I'm free, I like going swimming, going to exhibitions or to concerts if I have enough money. Oh, and every Sunday, I clean up the entire flat.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: And in the evening, I watch TV.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Oh, I never watch TV. It's boring.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Peter and I like going to the cinema at the weekend.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Yes, it's important not to watch too much TV. An hour a day or so, that's enough.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Come on, guys. You talk like my grandfather. Work, TV, housework on the weekends? Life is more.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: I want you to take me to places where young people have fun.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Great. Get ready, Grandpa.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Work is so hard, guys. I wake up at 6:30 every day. Have breakfast and take the train to work. Every day.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I know. I get up at 7:00, but I have a friend at work who usually gets up at 6:00.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Why? That's too early.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: It takes him an hour to drive to work.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Wow. That's a long drive.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes. But he lives in the country. I think he's lucky.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Every weekend he can go for walks in the woods. Not in traffic jams.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: I guess that's pretty nice. He lives in the countryside, but works in the city. A pretty nice combination.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: What about you, Sharon? What time do you wake up?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: I usually get up at about 9:00. But I live in the city. It's easy to get to work.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Yes, but you get home very late. Often 6:30 or 7:00.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: You know, I sometimes have five or six groups of tourists a day.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: You work too much, my dear.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And you sing too much, Peter.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Alice, I bet you don't wake up at 6:00 every day. Tell us something about your typical day at university.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Well, I sometimes have classes in the morning, but I usually have classes in the afternoon. On Mondays, I always attend lectures in the morning.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: And where do you study?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: I usually study in the library, but I sometimes study at home, too, when I don't have classes in the morning.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: My friend David also studies at your university. Do you remember him?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: David Leary?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Yes, I occasionally see him in the library and sometimes in the park.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: In the park? Doing what?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: He likes studying there. He takes his books, finds a nice park bench and reads there.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Not a bad idea. You can study and enjoy nature at the same time.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Yes, I like the park, too. Unfortunately, I often need books that are in the library.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: And what about lunch? Do you usually make sandwiches and take them with you?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Oh, no. I hate cooking. I usually have lunch in the cafeteria with friends.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Oh, I do just the opposite. I usually cook lunch at home. I seldom have a quick lunch at coffee shops.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Okay, guys. Stop with this boring talk. What about fun? Do any of you do anything besides working and studying? It's Friday, remember?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: You're right, Jack. I'm so happy it's Friday.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Me too. It's weekend time.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Time for shopping!

speaker: Speaker 2
text: May I ask you a question, Alice?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Sure. Ask any question you like. I'm an open book.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Do you have a boyfriend?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Well, I go out with some boys, but that's nothing serious. According to my birth chart, I need some Taurians. But that's not easy now that Saturn is in Leo.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: I see. Anyway, I think you have a strange relationship with boys.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Oh, no. I like boys very much. They're great at carrying packages.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: You're exceptional.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Thanks, Jack. But now, stop talking about me. Let's talk about you. What do you think of me?

speaker: Speaker 3
text: No, really. I'm curious. What do you do at work?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, nothing special. Um, you know Speedmaster, the sporting goods factory.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Yeah, sure, they produce wonderful running shoes. What department do you work in?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: I'm a sales manager. Last month they gave me a promotion and now I'm responsible for Southern Europe. That's why I moved here.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Wow, that's really interesting. You must be very good at work. What exactly do you do?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, basically, I look for new clients and keep them informed about new product lines and take care of their requests.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: What kind of requests do they have?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, they often ask questions about new models and prices.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: What do you do if they want a discount?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Well, basically, I don't get mad. I listen to them and then I tell them, no. Well, seriously speaking, it depends. Each client is different. If they're important, I try to make an agreement with them.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Hi, Anne. Hi, Sharon. Where's Peter?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Oh, Peter's preparing his audition.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Well, tell Peter I wish him good luck.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Do you really care?

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, girls, we're talking about jobs. Tell me about your job, Sharon. What do you do at the moment?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Ah, that's an interesting question.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Really? Why do you say that?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Well, you know I have a degree in archaeology, but now I'm doing something quite different.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Do you have a part-time job?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: No, unfortunately, it's a full-time job. I work for a travel agency.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, what do you do?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: I give tours around the city. I bring tourists to monuments and museums, and other interesting places.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Well, that's nice.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Could I have you as a tour guide for one day?

speaker: Speaker 4
text: I'm sorry. I only work with groups. Usually with Japanese people.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, well, I'm a black belt in karate.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Very funny, but it's not enough.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It's too bad.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Anne, stop cleaning for a moment. Sit down and tell me about your job.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Okay, okay, okay, okay.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I work in a publishing company.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Oh, so you work with famous writers?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Not exactly. Um, I don't work with the writers. I just read their proofs and correct them before printing.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Ah, by the way, do you know Paul Taylor? He works with you, right?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Yes, yes, but we don't work in the same department. He works in the advertising department.
